docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time since the AIDS epidemic began in 1981, the number of deaths from the disease has dropped ''substantially'' across the country, Federal health officials said today. The overall decline was about 12 percent -- to 22,000 in the first six months of 1996 from 24,900 in the same period of 1995 -- in all regions of the country, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in its weekly report. The rate of decrease in AIDS deaths was 16 percent in the West, 15 percent in the Northeast, 11 percent in the Midwest, and 8 percent in the South, the Federal health agency said.

headline.main: U.S. Reporting Sharp Decrease In AIDS Deaths

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that for first time since AIDS epidemic began in 1981, number of deaths from disease has dropped 'substantially' across country; says overall decline was about 12 percent--to 22,000 in first six months of 1996 from 24,900 in same period of 1995; says rate of decrease in AIDS deaths was 16 percent in West, 15 percent in Northeast, 11 percent in Midwest and 8 percent in South; national decline confirms trend that New York City health officials reported last month in announcing that their figures showed first documented drop in AIDS deaths in country; national decline is less than 30 percent drop reported in New York City; deaths from AIDS for women rose 3 percent in national data but dropped 24.5 percent for women in New York City; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Paula Lincoln of Rockland, Mass., lost her teaching job and her health insurance two years ago, but her sons, Christopher and Jeffrey, still get checkups and shots at a dollar a visit. Mark Leary of Lawrence works for a supermarket that does not offer health insurance, but he is still able to take his 3-year-old daughter, Kaitlynn, to doctors for treatment of her ear infections.
docs.abstract: Massachusetts Children's Medical Security Plan is intended to insure children whose parents earn too much to be eligible for Medicaid, but who cannot afford private health insurance; program is being paid for through increase in cigarette tax; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Government proposed today that labels on nonprescription drugs be simplified, a step the Secretary of Health and Human Services said would help ''anyone who ever takes a pain reliever, cough syrup or any of the thousands of other over-the-counter items on the market.'' Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said the changes were designed to do away with the small letters and dense prose that now blur the labels of some 125,000 over-the-counter drugs. A typical label, Dr. Kessler said, ''reads just like a legal contract'' and so is apt to be ignored.

headline.main: U.S. Acts to Simplify Labels on Medicine

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration proposes that labels on nonprescription drugs be simplified; Comr David A Kessler says changes are designed to do away with small letters and dense prose that now blur labels of some 125,000 over-the-counter drugs; Health and Human Services Sec Donna E Shalala says new labels will help consumers choose right medications and avoid harmful mistakes (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. May Punish Mexico For Drug Corruption American officials said Mexico might for the first time lose its status as a country that cooperates in the effort against drugs because of recent disclosures about ties between Mexican officials and drug traffickers. Mexico's Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo Cuellar, said that 36 employees had been dismissed from the federal drug agency and that every remaining staff member was being scrutinized for possible corruption. A1 Albright Meets China's Leaders Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said she ''told it like it is'' in her meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China and other leaders in Beijing, talking frankly on controversial issues like weapons sales and human rights. Little concrete progress was made, but Ms. Albright said she was ''encouraged'' that relations with China could improve. She said Vice President Al Gore would visit China next month. A11

docs.lead_paragraph: In a feat that may be the one bit of genetic engineering that has been anticipated and dreaded more than any other, researchers in Britain are reporting that they have cloned an adult mammal for the first time. The group, led by Dr. Ian Wilmut, a 52-year-old embryologist at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh, created a lamb using DNA from an adult sheep. The achievement shocked leading researchers who had said it could not be done. The researchers had assumed that the DNA of adult cells would not act like the DNA formed when a sperm's genes first mingle with those of an egg.

headline.main: SCIENTIST REPORTS FIRST CLONING EVER OF ADULT MAMMAL

docs.abstract: British researchers report cloning adult mammal for first time, genetic engineering feat anticipated and dreaded more than any other; group led by Dr Ian Wilmut, embryologist at Roslin Institute in Edinburgh, created lamb using deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) from adult sheep; achievement shocks researchers, who said it could not be done on assumption that DNA of adult cells would not act like DNA of formed when sperm's genes mingle with those of egg; researchers say technique could, theoretically, be used to create genetically identical human, or time-delayed twin; Wilmut's experiment described; he comments; foresees benefits for medicine, notably aiding in study of genetic diseases; other researchers comment; thorny ethical and philosophical questions raised by experiment discussed; diagram (M)
